106606 106606 S1566-7367(23)00008-0 10.1016/j.catcom.2023.106606 The Authors Fig. 1 Schematic representation of the tandem process used in the synthesis of IMIs. Step 1 involves the oxidation of BzOH to BzN, while step 2 is associated with the coupling between BzN and ANL. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Setup used in the catalytic tests. It is a continuous-flow system equipped with a fixed-bed stainless steel reactor. O2 was used as the sweep gas and the catalyst powder was loaded into the reactor using quartz wool. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Small-angle XRD pattern of (a) SBA-15 and (d) KIT-6. N2 sorption isotherms and pore size distribution of (b) SBA-15 and (e) KIT-6. TEM micrographs obtained for (c) SBA-15 and (f) KIT-6. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Wide-angle XRD patterns taken for (a) LM-C, (b) LM-S, and (c) LM-K. Inset: small-angle XRD patterns of these samples. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 N2 sorption isotherms and pore size distributions of (a) LM-C, (b) LM-S, and (c) LM-K. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 TEM micrographs of (a-c) LM-C, (f-h) LM-S, and (k-m) LM-K. Particle size distributions of (d) LM-C, (i) LM-S, and (n) LM-K. EDS spectra of (e) LM-C, (j) LM-S, and (o) LM-K. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 High-resolution TEM images of (a) LM-C, (c) LM-S, and (e) LM-K. SAED patterns of perovskites (b) LM-C, (d) LM-S, and (f) LM-K. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Catalytic behavior of LM-C as a function of (a) the reaction temperature(1) and (b) O2 flow rate(2). Conditions: molar ratio of BzOH: ANL = 1:1, BzOH (QBzOH) flow = 1 mmol.h−1, solvent-free, catalyst mass = 400 mg, reaction time = 2 h, pressure = 1 atm. (1)Temperature range of 200–260 °C with QO2 = 20 mL.min−1 to determine the ideal temperature. (2)O2 flow range of 10–40 mL.min−1 using the ideal temperature to determine the optimal O2 flow rate. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 XPS spectra of La 3d, Mn 2p, and O 1 s for LM-C (a, b, c), LM-S (d, e, f), and LM-K (g, h, i). Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Catalytic behavior of LM-C, LM-S, and LM-K for (a) Conversion of BzOH to BzD, (b) Selectivity for IMI formation by coupling BzD to ANL, and (c) FR(IMI)/m. Conditions: molar ratio of BzOH: ANL = 1:1, BzOH (QBzOH) flow = 1 mmol.h−1, O2 (QO2) flow = 15 mL.min−1, solvent-free, catalysts masses = LM-C (400 mg), LM-S (200 mg), and LM-K (200 mg). Tests conducted keeping the reaction temperature and O2 flow rate constant at 260 °C and 15 mL.min−1, respectively. Presidente Antônio Carlos, 6627, Pampulha, CEP: 31270-901 Belo Horizonte, Minas Gerais, Brazil ⁎ Corresponding author. We report here a green methodology for the synthesis of imine from a gas-phase oxidative coupling of benzyl alcohol to aniline in a continuous-flow system. These reactions were performed using LaMNO3 perovskites as heterogeneous catalysts. The catalytic performance of these materials was 98% and remained stable for 8 h of reaction. The prepared catalysts were successfully regenerated and reused in five successive catalytic cycles. No organic solvents were used in this process, which represents an important advantage in terms of the environment, simplicity, and safety. Moreover, this approach reduces the need for subsequent physicochemical extraction and purification steps. Graphical abstract Unlabelled Image Keywords Perovskites Nanocasting Mesoporous structure Imine synthesis Gas-phase reactions Continuous flow Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Imines (IMIs) have the general formula R'RC=NR”, where R, R', and R" can be hydrogen atoms, alkyl groups, and aryl groups, respectively [1,2]. Due to their multifunctional bonds, IMIs are a key class of intermediates in the synthesis of several biologically-active N-heterocyclic compounds. Moreover, they have been employed in many industrial sectors, including agriculture and pharmaceuticals [3]. IMIs can act as electrophiles [4] in reactions such as reduction, condensation, addition, asymmetric organocatalysis, and multicomponent reactions [5]. Due to this behavior, an increasing demand for the synthesis of these compounds has been reported in recent years [6,7]. Among the methods employed in the production of IMIs, the tandem catalytic process between amines and alcohols deserves to be highlighted because alcohols are more stable and cost-effective than aldehydes, amines, and alkynes. Moreover, water is the only by-product of these processes [8,9]. The tandem mechanism for the synthesis of IMIs from alcohols and aniline (ANL) consists of two steps (Fig. 1 ). Benzyl alcohol (BzOH) is initially oxidized to benzaldehyde (BzD), which is the rate-limiting step of this process. BzD is subsequently coupled with ANL to produce IMI. Homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts have been employed in these reactions. Strong inorganic (e.g., potassium hydroxide and sodium hydroxide) and organic bases (e.g., 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane), and solvents (e.g., benzene and mesitylene) have been also used in these reactions [7,10,11]. Nonetheless, this process is usually complex, multi-step, and time-consuming. Consequently, the development of novel heterogeneous catalysts could improve the production of IMIs for different industrial applications. Different catalysts have been employed in the synthesis of IMI by oxidative coupling reactions. Among these materials, Mn-containing catalysts have shown promising results. Bu et al. [7] evaluated the redox properties of different MnO2 samples. The yield of IMI formation after 12 h of reaction at 60 °C for α-MnO2, β-MnO2, and γ-MnO2 was 27.4%, 43.9%, and 98.1%, respectively. The high catalytic activity of γ-MnO2 was associated with the abundance of Mn3+ ions, hydroxyl-like groups, and acidic sites on it. Chen et al. [12] reported the synthesis of IMIs from alcohols and amines using a heterogeneous catalyst based on metal nanoparticles (PdAu alloy) anchored onto a metal-organic framework containing Mn. The authors reported that the coexistence of Mn in two oxidation states (Mn3+/Mn4+) favors both the electron transfer and generation of reactive oxygen species. Chutimasakul et al. [13] investigated the catalytic performance of amorphous CeMn oxides with hierarchical microsphere structures. The improved catalytic activity of these materials was attributed to the coexistence of Mn3+/Mn4+ and Ce3+/Ce4+ species, which could favor the formation of oxygen vacancies and active surface oxygen species. Moreover, the oxygen storage ability could also be increased, also contributing to the catalytic behavior of the prepared samples. Qin et al. [11] evaluated the synthesis of imine by the oxidative coupling of BzOH and ANL over an amorphous Fe2O3-modified Mn3O4 catalyst. They reported selectivity for IMI formation of 99% at 60 °C after 12 h of reaction. This improved catalytic performance has been attributed to the synergistic effect between the Fe3+/Fe2+ and Mn3+/Mn2+ redox, which plays an important role in transferring the chemisorbed oxygen species from Fe2O3 to Mn3O4 during the catalytic process. Perovskites have the general formula ABO3, where the A-site is usually occupied by a rare-earth cation and the B-site is filled by a transition metal cation. The presence of cations in mixed oxidation states confers catalytic properties to perovskites, favoring the generation of oxygen vacancies and increasing the ionic mobility through its lattice [14,15]. Perovskites are materials of high technological importance and are used in a range of applications, including sensing [16,17], batteries [18,19], supercapacitors [20,21], and solar cells [22,23]. Among the studied perovskites, LaMnO3 is a promising material for heterogeneous catalysis due to the coexistence of manganese as Mn3+/Mn4+ in its structure [24–26]. Moreover, this material has a high capacity for oxygen adsorption, reduction, and diffusion [27], good thermal stability, and high chemical inertness at high temperatures [28]. Because of this behavior, this perovskite has been used as a substitute for noble metal catalysts in a range of applications [24,29–39]. Perovskites are usually obtained after heat treatment above 700 °C because lower temperatures can lead to phases other than perovskite. Nonetheless, this step can cause particle agglomeration and decrease porosity; surface areas below 10 m2.g−1 have been reported for these materials [40–43]. This behavior impairs their catalytic activity since this property is closely related to the catalyst surface area. Nanocasting, also known as hard templating, exotemplating, or repeated templating, is an effective technique to obtain mesoporous oxides [44,45]. This method generally uses silica as a hard template, which allows the pore morphology to be tailored and leads to samples with high specific surface areas and tunable pore sizes [46]. These templates can exhibit either two- or three-dimensional pore structures [47], and usually have high mechanical, hydrothermal, and thermal stabilities. Among these silica-based templates [47], SBA-15 (Santa Barbara Amorphous) and KIT-6 (Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology) are often used in the preparation of mesoporous perovskites [24,48–51]. SBA-15 has a two-dimensional hexagonal pore structure (space group p6mm), while KIT-6 has a three-dimensional cylindrical pore structure (space group Ia3d) [47,52–54]. Both templates have thick pore walls, high specific surface area, good thermal stability, and attractive mechanical properties. In this work, we report for the first time a green methodology for the straightforward synthesis of IMI by the oxidative coupling of BzOH to ANL in a continuous-flow system. Mesoporous LaMnO3 was employed as the heterogeneous catalyst in these reactions. This material was initially prepared using either SBA-15 or KIT-6 as a hard template and then compared to a perovskite obtained by the conventional citrate method. No organic solvents were used in this process, which is a great advantage in terms of the environment, simplicity, and safety. Moreover, this approach reduces the need for subsequent physicochemical extraction and purification steps, which is in line with the principles of green chemistry [55]. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Starting materials The following materials were used in this study as received and without further purification. Poly(ethylene glycol)-block-poly(propylene glycol)-block-poly(ethylene glycol) (EO20PO70EO20, Pluronic P123, MWaverage = 5800), hydrochloric acid (HCl, 37%), tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 98%), 1-butanol (99.8%), ethanol (EtOH, 99.8%), lanthanum (III) nitrate hexahydrate (La(NO3)3·6H2O, 99,99%), manganese (II) nitrate tetrahydrate (Mn(NO3)2·4H2O, 97%), anhydrous sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 98%) and citric acid monohydrate (99,99%). All these reagents were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. Aqueous solutions were prepared using Milli-Q deionized water (18.2 MΩ.cm at 25 °C). Oxygen gas (O2, 99.5% purity) was supplied by Messer Americas. 2.2 Silica templates SBA-15 was prepared following the procedure described by Nair et al. [36] and Deng et al. [56]. In a typical synthesis, P123 (13.9 g) is dissolved under stirring at 40 °C in a solution of H2O (252 g) and HCl (7.7 g). TEOS (25 g) is subsequently added and the as-obtained solution is stirred at 40 °C for 24 h. Next, the solution is poured into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heat-treated at 100 °C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting material is filtered, washed with H2O, and air-dried at 80 °C for 24 h. The obtained powder is then calcined in air at 550 °C for 6 h using a heating rate of 1 °C.min−1. This step promotes the thermal degradation of P123 and gives rise to mesopores in the silica network. KIT-6 was obtained according to the method reported by Deng et al. [56] and Kleitz et al. [57]. Typically, P123 (9 g) is initially dissolved in a solution of H2O (325 g) and HCl (17.4 g) under stirring at 40 °C. 1-butanol (9 g) is then added and the as-obtained solution is stirred at 40 °C for 1 h. TEOS (19.4 g) is subsequently added and the mixture is stirred at 40 °C for another 24 h. The solution is then transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heat-treated at 100 °C for 24 h. The obtained material is filtered, washed with H2O, and air-dried at 80 °C for 24 h. A calcination step is then conducted at 550 °C and 1 °C.min−1 for 6 h to remove P123 from the silica network. 2.3 Mesoporous perovskites Nanocast LaMnO3 was prepared following the procedure suggested by Nair et al. [36] and Deng et al. [56]. In this approach, SBA-15 and KIT-6 are used as hard templates, while a citrate complex of metal cations is employed as the precursor. In a typical synthesis, either SBA-15 or KIT-6 (1 g) is dispersed in H2O (10 mL) under stirring for 2 h. In another flask, La(NO3)3·6H2O (3 mmol), Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (3 mmol), and citric acid (3 mmol) are dispersed under stirring for 4 h in a solution of EtOH and H2O (20 mL, volume ratio of EtOH: H2O = 3: 1). The as-prepared solution is then added dropwise to the aqueous suspension containing the silica template, and the molar ratio of metal ions to citric acid is kept at 2:1. The mixture is stirred at 70 °C for 24 h to eliminate solvents, and the gel obtained is air-dried at 80 °C for 24 h. The material prepared is subsequently powdered and heat-treated at 200 °C for 2 h and at 500 °C for 3 h using a heating rate of 1 °C min−1. This step promotes the removal of citric acid and nitrate ions (NO3 −) from the prepared material. A subsequent impregnation step was conducted following a procedure similar to that described before, but using half the amount (1.5 mmol) of the precursors (citric acid and metal nitrates). The obtained powder was heat-treated in air at 700 °C for 5 h with a heating rate of 1 °C.min−1. The silica template was removed by washing the powder three times with a NaOH aqueous solution (2 mol.L−1) at room temperature. The obtained material was filtered and washed with H2O and EtOH to pH 7, and then air-dried for 24 h at 80 °C. Nanocast specimens obtained using SBA-15 or KIT-6 were designated as LM-S or LM-K, respectively. A LaMnO3 powder was also obtained by the conventional citrate method for comparison purposes. The molar ratio and heat treatment conditions above mentioned were employed in the preparation of this sample, which was denoted as LM-C. The synthesis procedure used in this work is described elsewhere [26,58]. 2.4 Structural characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) was conducted on a Philips-PANalytical PW 1710 diffractometer operating at 40 mA and 40 kV. The XRD patterns were collected at a scan speed of either 0.02°.min−1 (2θ = 0.4–4.0°) or 0.06°.min−1 (2θ = 3–90°). The crystallite size (Ds – nm) was evaluated from the Scherrer equation (Eq. (1)), where K is a dimensionless shape factor (0.9), λ is the wavelength of the X-ray source (CuKα = 0.15406 nm), β is the full width at half maximum (rad), and θ is the Bragg angle (rad). (1) D s = K λ β Cos θ Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), and selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) were carried out on an FEI Tecnai G2–20 SuperTwin microscope at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. This microscope is coupled to a Si(Li) EDS detector (EDAX). The samples used in these tests were initially dispersed in EtOH under sonication at room temperature for 5 min. The as-obtained suspension was then dripped onto carbon-coated copper grids and air-dried at room temperature. These grids were subsequently transferred to the electron microscope and examined. N2 sorption was conducted at −196 °C on a Quantachrome Autosorb IQ2, using samples outgassed under vacuum at 200 °C for 12 h. The specific surface area was assessed by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The pore size distribution was evaluated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model considering the desorption branch. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a Specs Phoibos 150 analyzer equipped with a monochromatic X-ray source of 1486.6 eV (AlKα). All peaks were calibrated using the C 1 s binding energy at 284.8 eV as a reference. The high-resolution spectra were collected at a step size of 0.1 eV and pass energy of 25 eV. 2.5 Catalytic tests 2.5.1 Experimental setup Fig. 2 shows the setup used in the catalytic tests. These experiments were performed on a continuous-flow fixed-bed stainless-steel reactor with an inner diameter of 6 mm. The reactor was placed in a vertical tubular furnace and the temperature was monitored using a K-type thermocouple kept in contact with the reactor surface. Quartz wool was placed in the reactor core and the catalyst powder was added to it. No compression or vibration steps were applied to accommodate the catalyst powder in the quartz wool. An equimolar mixture of BzOH and ANL was initially prepared and then co-feed with O2. The BzOH flow was kept at 1 mmol.h−1 in all catalytic tests. After each reaction, the catalyst was collected and the quartz wool was replaced with fresh wool. The catalytic conditions were optimized using LM-C as a reference. For this, the catalyst mass and reaction time were kept constant at 400 mg and 2 h, while the reaction temperature and O2 flow rate were varied in the ranges of 200–260 °C and 10–40 mL.min−1, respectively. The influence of the reaction temperature and flow rate on the catalytic behavior of the perovskites was evaluated as a function of BzOH conversion and selectivity for IMI formation. During these tests, the catalyst mass was fixed at 400 mg for LM-C, 200 mg for LM-S, and 200 mg for LM-K. Thus, the masses of the catalysts obtained by the nanocasting method correspond to half the mass of the catalyst derived from the conventional citrate method; this behavior is associated with the smaller surface area evaluated for LM-C compared to either LM-K or LM-S. The reaction time varied from 1 h to 8 h. 2.5.2 Analysis of catalytic products Products derived from the catalytic reactions were examined on an Agilent 7890B gas chromatography (GC) system coupled to an Agilent 5977B mass detector (MS). The analysis parameters were the following: injection volume = 0.5 μL (division 100); injector temperature = 250 °C; He flow rate = 1.2 mL.min−1; detector temperature = 150 °C. The GC column was initially kept at 40 °C for 1 min and then heated up to 250 °C at 20 °C.min−1. The conversion efficiency of BzOH to BzD (%), the selectivity for IMI formation (%), and the formation rate of IMI (mmol.h−1) per mass of catalyst (g) [FR(IMI)/m - (mmol.h−1).g−1] were evaluated by Eq. (2), Eq. (3), and Eq. (4), respectively, where [BzOH]i is the amount of BzOH (mmol) injected into the reactor, [BzOH]r is the amount of BzOH (mmol) in the product after the catalytic reaction, [IMI] is the amount of IMI (mmol) formed and identified in the examined product, Σproducts represents the sum of the amounts (mmol) of all chemical compounds detected in the analyzed product, MLaMnO3 is the catalytic mass (g), and t is the reaction time (h). (2) Conversion of BzOH % = BzOH i − BzOH r BzOH i × 100 % (3) Selectivity for IMI % = IMI ∑ products × 100 % (4) FR IMI / m mmol . h − 1 . g − 1 = IMI t × 1 M LaMnO 3 2.5.3 Reusability and structural stability To evaluate the structural stability and reusability of the prepared catalysts, the following procedure was used. After 8 h of reaction under continuous flow, the catalysts were removed from the reactor and examined by XRD. They were then washed three times with EtOH and H2O to remove residual organic compounds and subsequently collected by centrifugation. They were then air-dried at 80 °C for 24 h and then heat-treated for 5 h at 500 °C using heating and cooling rates of 1 °C.min−1. The catalysts were used in five catalytic cycles. At the end of each 8 h reaction cycle, the collected product was examined by GC–MS. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 SBA-15 and KIT-6 Fig. 3 shows small-angle XRD patterns, N2 sorption isotherms, pore size distributions, and TEM micrographs taken for SBA-15 and KIT-6. The textural properties obtained for these silica samples are given in Table 1 . SBA-15 exhibits XRD peaks corresponding to (100), (110), and (200) reflections (Fig. 3a), which have been ascribed to a 2D-hexagonal structure with p6mm symmetry [33,59]. KIT-6 shows XRD peaks associated with (211), (220), and (321) reflections (Fig. 3d), which evidences the presence of a 3D-cubic structure with Ia3d symmetry [60,61]. The N2 sorption isotherms taken for these materials are type-IV isotherms with H1 hysteresis loops [62]. Capillary condensation took place at relative pressures of 0.6–0.8 for SBA-15 (Fig. 3b) [33,61] and 0.3–0.8 for KIT-6 (Fig. 3e) [54,61]. These isotherms reveal that these templates are mesoporous, which is in agreement with the TEM images displayed in Fig. 3c (SBA-15) and Fig. 3f (KIT-6). According to the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) [62], mesopores are between 2 nm and 50 nm in size. As shown in Table 1, the specific surface area and pore volume evaluated for KIT-6 were 750 m2.g−1 and 1.10 cm3.g−1, while for SBA-15 they were estimated at 734 m2.g−1 and 0.83 cm3.g−1. One observes that the pore size distribution of KIT-6 is shifted to smaller sizes relative to SBA-15; the former exhibits two peaks at 3.6 nm and 6.6 nm, while the latter exhibits two peaks at 6.7 nm and 8.8 nm. The larger pore size of SBA-15 compared to KIT-6 may favor the access of oxide precursors to the pore structure of the former during the nanocasting step. 3.2 LaMnO3 perovskites Fig. 4 displays the wide-angle XRD patterns of LM-C, LM-S, and LM-K. These patterns have been related to LaMnO3.15 (JCPDS Card No. 50–0298), which exhibits a rhombohedral structure (R-3c space group). No peaks associated with La2O3 or MnO2 were observed. The XRD peaks observed at 23.0°, 32.8°, 40.2°, 47.0°, 52.6°, 58.2°, 68.7°, and 77.9°, are associated with the (012), (110), (202), (024), (122), (214), (208), and (134) crystal planes. The crystallite size of these materials was evaluated by the Scherrer equation (Eq. 1). It was found that LM-C, LM-K, and LM-S have crystallites of about 59 nm, 12 nm, and 8 nm in size. Thus, it is clear that nanocast samples (LM-K and LM-S) have smaller crystallite sizes compared to the sample obtained from the conventional citrate method (LM-C). The small-angle XRD patterns of these materials are shown in the insets of Fig. 4a-c. No peaks associated with the ordered silica templates are noted in these patterns, revealing that they were successfully removed during the etching step with the NaOH solution. Fig. 5 shows the N2 sorption isotherms taken for the prepared perovskites. LM-C showed a narrow hysteresis loop at relative pressures above 0.8, in addition to surface area and pore volume of 11 m2.g−1 and 0.10 cm3.g−1 (Table 1). The average pore size estimated for this sample was about 72 nm, revealing that it has a macroporous structure [63]. According to IUPAC [62], macropores are larger than 50 nm. On the other hand, LM-S and LM-K showed wide hysteresis loops and surface areas of 87 m2.g−1 and 95 m2.g−1, respectively. The specific pore volume and average pore size assessed for these materials were about 0.8 cm3.g−1 and 18 nm. This behavior suggests that LM-S and LM-K display mesoporous structures [63], which has already been reported for nanocast specimens [24,46,60]. The higher surface area and pore volume of LM-S and LM-K compared to LM-C may positively affect the catalytic behavior of these specimens by favoring the contact of reactant molecules with active sites on their surface. TEM revealed that LM-C has agglomerated particles (Fig. 6a-c) with an average particle size of about 90 nm (Fig. 6d and Table 1). The large size and irregular shape of these particles are due to the heat treatment conducted at 700 °C for 5 h. As mentioned before, this step is mandatory to obtain perovskites with high phase purity. Nonetheless, it causes particle agglomeration and decreases porosity. TEM micrographs taken for LM-S (Fig. 6f-h) and LM-K (Fig. 6k-m) revealed the prevalence of a disordered pore network. This behavior can be attributed to (i) the incomplete filling of the mesoporous structure of SBA-15 and KIT-6 by the metal precursors, (ii) the use of a subsequent impregnation step to achieve a higher loading of metal precursors, and (iii) the removal of silica templates responsible for the ordered pore networks. LM-S (Fig. 6i) showed a particle size distribution of 4–13 nm with an average particle size of 8.3 nm, while LM-K (Fig. 6n) has a particle size distribution of 9–18 nm and an average particle size of 13.5 nm (Table 1). The chemical composition of the prepared catalysts was evaluated by EDS (Fig. 6e, Fig. 6j, and Fig. 6o). The peak ascribed to Cu is associated with the copper grids used in these analyzes. Signals related to La, Mn, and O can be observed for the catalysts examined, which reinforces the formation of LaMnO3. A peak associated with Si was detected in the EDS spectra of LM-S (Fig. 6j) and LM-K (Fig. 6o), which may be due to the incomplete removal of silica during the etching of the catalyst powder with a NaOH aqueous solution. It has been reported that residual silica can be due to [64,65] (i) the strong interaction of silica with rare earth elements, and (ii) the encapsulation of silica particles during the impregnation step with metal precursors. It is worth noting that this impregnation procedure was conducted twice aiming to increase the concentration of metal precursors in the silica template. As shown in Fig. 7b, Fig. 7d, and Fig. 7f, the prepared catalysts showed well-resolved Debye-Scherrer rings, which have been assigned to polycrystalline materials. Nonetheless, the SAED patterns of LM-S and LM-K have lower intensities than LM-C, suggesting that the nanocast materials display smaller particles than the sample derived from the conventional citrate method. This finding is in agreement with XRD and TEM (Table 1). The lattice fringe spacing evaluated for LM-C (Fig. 7a), LM-S (Fig. 7c), and LM-K (Fig. 7e) was about 0.275 nm, corresponding to the (110) crystal plane associated with the XRD peak at 2θ = 32.8° (Fig. 4a). The SAED and TEM results suggest that the prepared catalysts are perovskite-type LaMnO3.15 powders. 3.3 Catalytic tests 3.3.1 Reaction conditions optimization Fig. 8 shows the influence of the reaction temperature and O2 flow rate on the catalytic behavior of LM-C. It can be observed that increasing the reaction temperature from 200 °C to 260 °C has improved the catalytic activity of this material; an optimal ratio between the conversion capacity (49.4%) and selectivity (69.4%) was obtained at 260 °C. Besides, changes in the O2 flow rate also influenced the catalytic behavior of LM-C and the highest selectivity (75.2%) was obtained for a gas flow of 15 mL.min−1. Fig. 9 depicts XPS spectra taken for the samples prepared in this study. As will be discussed later, LM-C has a high concentration of Mn3+/Mn4+ pairs, adsorbed oxygen, and lattice oxygen on its surface. Increasing the reaction temperature enhances the mobility of adsorbed oxygen species, which play a key role in redox reactions [25,66–68]. As these species are consumed, they give rise to oxygen vacancies and increase the oxygen storage capacity of the catalyst. The filling of surface oxygen vacancies by gas-phase O2 leads to additional reactive oxygen species, favoring the catalytic reactions [69–71]. In addition, increasing the O2 flow favors the transport of reactant molecules to the catalyst surface, positively affecting the kinetics of the oxidation and coupling reactions [72–75]. Based on these findings, we kept the reaction temperature and O2 flow rate fixed at 260 °C and 15 mL.min−1. Under these conditions, LM-C showed a conversion efficiency of 46.1% and selectivity of 75.2%. Azobenzene was detected as a by-product of these reactions at concentrations below 1%. It is also worth mentioning that a high amount of energy was released for reactions performed above 260 °C, causing an additional 15 °C increase in the reactor temperature. Due to this behavior, the catalytic reactions were carried out at temperatures up to 260 °C. 3.3.2 Catalytic behavior of nanocast perovskites Fig. 10 shows the catalytic results of the perovskites prepared here. It was observed that LM-S and LM-K showed better catalytic performance than LM-C. This last catalyst had an FR(IMI)/m of 0.38 mmol.h−1.g−1 (Fig. 10c) but a decrease in the catalytic activity with time. On the one hand, LM-C displayed a conversion efficiency of 22.0% (Fig. 10a) and selectivity of 59.5% (Fig. 10b) in the first hour of reaction. On the other hand, its conversion rate and selectivity decreased to 1.0% and 49.4% after 8 h, which represents a reduction of 95.3% and 16.9%, respectively. The conversion (Fig. 10a), selectivity (Fig. 10b), and FR(IMI)/m (Fig. 10c) evaluated for the nanocast catalysts were 97.7%, 98.2%, and 4.5 mmol.h−1.g−1 for LM-S, and 83.2%, 85.3%, and 4.1 mmol.h−1.g−1 for LM-K. Therefore, the perovskites obtained in this study can be ranked according to their catalytic performance as follows: LM-S > LM-K > LM-C. This finding suggests that the specific surface area, pore volume, and crystallite size play an important role in the catalytic reactions conducted in this study. As described before, LM-K, LM-S, and LM-C showed surface areas of about 95 m2.g−1, 87 m2.g−1, and 11 m2.g−1. LM-C displayed a specific pore volume of about 0.1 cm3.g−1, while the pore volume evaluated for LM-K and LM-S was around 0.8 cm3.g−1. The crystallite size estimated for LM-C, LM-K, and LM-S was 59 nm, 12 nm, and 8 nm, respectively. Therefore, it appears that the smaller the crystallite size and the larger the surface area and pore volume, the greater the number of sites available for catalysis. This behavior significantly enhances the catalytic activity of the perovskite powder, which is observed for LM-K and LM-S. It has been reported that the kinetics of the oxidative coupling of BzD to ANL is largely related to the diffusion of reagent molecules into the catalyst pores and the subsequent desorption of the products, which makes these active sites available for the adsorption of new reactant molecules [72–75]. Thus, the textural properties of the catalyst powder have a great influence on its catalytic behavior. It can be observed from TEM (Fig. 6) that LM-S has a crystallite size 58% smaller than that estimated for LM-K (8 nm versus 14 nm), which may contribute to the better catalytic activity of the former. In a previous study [76], we prepared LaMnO3 perovskites by a sol-gel approach and after heat treatment at 700 °C for 5 h. These materials were then evaluated according to their catalytic behavior for IMI formation in the same fixed-bed reactor used here. It was observed that particle agglomeration took place during the heat treatment step, which led to samples with a surface area of about 12 m2.g−1. The conversion efficiency assessed for these materials was around 87.0%, a lower value than that reported here for LM-S (97.9%). Thus, it is clear that the use of the nanocasting approach positively affected the textural properties and catalytic behavior of LaMnO3 perovskite. The XPS spectra of La 3d, Mn 2p, and O 1 s are shown in Fig. 9. The deconvolution of these spectra was performed using Gaussian functions and the contribution of each peak is given in Table 2 . The peaks at about 834 eV and 851 eV have been assigned to La 3d5/2 and La 3d3/2, respectively. Their corresponding satellite peaks are observed at about 838 eV and 854 eV [8,77,78]. The Mn 2p XPS spectra were fitted by two main peaks corresponding to the Mn 2p3/2 and the Mn 2p1/2 spin-orbit peaks located at about 642 eV and 653 eV. After deconvolution, four characteristic peaks can be observed, which have been attributed to the coexistence of Mn3+ (642 eV and 653 eV) and Mn4+ (645 eV and 656 eV) species on the oxide surface [24,78]. The catalysts showed the following sequence for the concentration of Mn3+ on their surfaces: LM-S > LM-K > LM-C. The high content of Mn3+ species on LM-S provides high catalytic efficiency to this material because electrons derived from the oxidation of Mn3+ to Mn4+ can participate in the catalytic reactions [24]. Besides, the presence of Mn3+ species can lead to oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface, increasing the oxygen storage capacity and favoring the catalytic process [78]. The O 1 s XPS spectra were fitted using two peaks attributed to surface adsorbed oxygen species (OA) at 531 eV and lattice oxygen species (OL) at 529 eV. As reported elsewhere [78,79], adsorbed oxygen species (OA) exhibit higher mobility than lattice oxygen species (OL), which favors catalytic activity in oxidation reactions. Redox reactions take place during the catalytic process, causing the oxidation of surface Mn3+ to Mn4+ [67]. Electrons derived from the oxidation of organic compounds can promote the reduction of Mn4+ to Mn3+. The existence of highly reactive adsorbed oxygen species (O2 2−/O−) on the catalyst surface also plays an important role in redox reactions [7,11,13]. As these oxygen species are consumed, Mn3+ is oxidized to Mn4+ [80]. Similarly, surface vacancies can adsorb molecular oxygen (O2), and new surface oxygen species are created, promoting the reduction of Mn4+ to Mn3+ [81]. Table 2 exhibits the concentration of OA in the examined catalysts; they can be ranked in the following sequence: LM-S > LM-K > LM-C. These results indicate that LM-S exhibits a higher concentration of OA than LM-K and LM-C, revealing that oxygen species have improved mobility in its lattice, which positively affects its catalytic behavior. Ansari et al. [82] used batch processing and obtained a conversion rate of 29.2% of BzOH after 12 h of reaction at 120 °C using 300 mg of sol-gel derived LaMnO3 and 2 mmol of BzOH diluted in 10 mL of toluene, which corresponds to about 0.2 mmol.h−1.g−1. Cao et al. [8] evaluated the continuous synthesis of IMI from BzOH and ANL using γ-Al2O3-CeO2 (γ-Al2O3 spheres coated with CeO2 and heat-treated at 500 °C) as the catalyst in a fixed-bed reactor. After 24 h of reaction performed at 140 °C, the production rate of IMI was 26.67 mmol.h−1.g−1, while the conversion of BzOH and selectivity of IMI were 99% and 98%, respectively. The authors reported that this result is related to the abundance of acid sites on γ-Al2O3 as well as the synergistic effect between CeO2 and γ-Al2O3. Nonetheless, the authors did not consider the mass of γ-Al2O3 (about 6650 mg) in these calculations, but only the mass of CeO2 (about 350 mg). This assumption greatly improved the efficiency of the examined samples. Wu et al. [10] studied the synthesis of IMI via the oxidative coupling of BzOH with amine using mesoporous manganese‑zirconium catalysts (Mn1Zr0.5Oy). They used a batch process with the following reaction conditions: molar ratio of BzOH to ANL of 1: 1.5, 60 mg of catalyst, 5 mL of toluene, reactions carried out in air at 1 atm, temperature of 80 °C, and reaction time of 3 h. The authors reported an IMI production rate of 5.56 mmol.h−1.g−1, with a BzOH conversion and selectivity for IMI formation of 100% and 99%, respectively. According to them, the good catalytic performance of this catalyst is due to its mesoporous structure, leading to a large specific surface area and a high availability of Mn3+ ions and reactive oxygen species to participate in the catalytic reactions. In this work, we showed that BzOH conversion efficiency, IMI selectivity, and FR(IMI)/m reached 97.7%, 98.2%, and 4.5 mmol.h−1.g−1 after 8 h for reactions carried out at 260 °C, using 200 mg of the mesoporous LaMnO3 (LM-S), molar ratio of BzOH to ANL of 1: 1, flow rates of BzOH and O2 of 1 mmol.h−1 and 15 mL.min−1, inner diameter of the reaction tube of 6 mm, filling height of the catalyst bed of 8 mm. Thus, we reached conversion efficiency and IMI selectivity similar to those reported in the literature despite of using smaller amounts of catalyst and lower reactant flow rates, which reinforces the high efficiency of the catalysts prepared here. 3.3.3 Reusability and structural stability The reusability of the catalysts was evaluated after 8 h of reaction (Fig. 11a). It can be observed that the nanocast perovskites were able to maintain a high yield of IMI (96% for LM-S and 80% for LM-K) after five successive catalytic cycles. Furthermore, these materials maintained their structural integrity after these cycles. As evidenced in Fig. 11b, no crystalline phases other than LaMnO3 were observed for these samples after these tests. These results reveal that the catalyst prepared here can be recovered, regenerated, and employed in successive catalytic cycles. From an industrial point of view, a heterogeneous catalyst must have not only efficient catalytic activity and selectivity but also stable regeneration [83]. The materials obtained in this work meet these requirements. 4 Conclusions In this study, we demonstrate for the first time the potential industrial use of mesoporous perovskite LaMnO3 catalysts in the synthesis of IMI by the oxidative coupling of BzOH to ANL in a gas-phase continuous-flow system. This process avoids the use of excess reagents, solvents, and the generation of hazardous substances. The nanocast catalyst obtained using mesoporous SBA-15 as the hard template (LM-S) showed a high and stable production of IMI (98.2%) after 8 h of reaction. In addition, this material could be successfully reactivated after washing, air-drying, and heat treatment, revealing good structural stability and catalytic performance in different cycles. The improved performance of mesoporous LaMnO3 can be attributed to its increased specific surface area and pore volume, which contributed to a greater amount of active sites available during the catalytic tests. This material was had a high concentration of Mn3+/Mn4+ pairs and adsorbed oxygen species (O2 2−/O−) on this material, which play an important role in redox reactions. This work was developed under the principles of green chemistry to contribute to the industry with a new sustainable methodology for the preparation of IMI, reducing operational costs and mitigating waste generation. It is notable that reducing solvent consumption and using fewer processing steps reduces costs and increases production efficiency. In this way, this work provides environmental and economic advantages, acting as an incentive for the industry to adopt greener technologies. coredata.dc:description: We report here a green methodology for the synthesis of imine from a gas-phase oxidative coupling of benzyl alcohol to aniline in a continuous-flow system. These reactions were performed using LaMNO3 perovskites as heterogeneous catalysts. The catalytic performance of these materials was 98% and remained stable for 8 h of reaction. The prepared catalysts were successfully regenerated and reused in five successive catalytic cycles. No organic solvents were used in this process, which represents an important advantage in terms of the environment, simplicity, and safety. Moreover, this approach reduces the need for subsequent physicochemical extraction and purification steps.
